bioghist.p: George Robert Sims (1847-1922) was an English journalist, dramatist, and poet. In 1874, Sims was invited to join the staff of Fun, a downmarket Punch, to replace Tom Hood. In 1876, employing the pseudonym Dagonet, he began to write "Mustard and Cress," a weekly column for the Referee that appeared without fail until the week of his death forty-six years later. His reports of some of his forays into the worst of London slums, commissioned by Pictorial World, were subsequently published as How the Poor Live (1883). Sims's first play, Crutch and Toothpick, was produced at the Royalty Theatre in April 1879, and was followed by a number of plays of which he was author or part-author. After long runs at West End houses, many of these became stock pieces in suburban and provincial theaters. His most famous melodramas were The Lights of London, In the Ranks, and Harbour Lights.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the correspondence of George Robert Sims. Included in the collection are letters from J.M. Barrie, Jerome K. Jerome, Hall Caine, Ingleby Oddie (on the subject of Arthur Conan Doyle and spiritualism), Lillie Langtree, Andrew Chatto, H.B. Irving, and others. Many of the letters discuss Sims' journalism and plays, social work, and appointments. The collection also includes letters from Sims to Clement Scott, a dramatic critic (mainly for the Daily Telegraph) and playwright. In addition the collection contains a small batch of playbills, cabinet cards, postcards, menus, tickets, and clippings.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
